title: Home Router WPS Vulnerability Assessment
description: Security assessment targeting WPS (WiFi Protected Setup) vulnerability on home router. Demonstrates how WPS PIN brute force attack can compromise router security even with strong WPA2 password.
scenario: Client reported suspicion that their home router may be vulnerable despite having a strong password. Investigation reveals WPS is enabled. Your task is to assess WPS security using wash scanner and reaver PIN attack.

steps.action: Enable monitor mode on wireless interface for WPS reconnaissance
steps.expected_result: Monitor mode enabled on wlan0mon - wireless card ready for WPS scanning
steps.explanation: Monitor mode required for both WPS scanning and PIN attack execution

steps.action: Scan for WPS-enabled access points in range
steps.expected_result: Found 8 WPS-enabled APs - Target 'HomeRouter-5G' (BSSID: 11:22:33:44:55:66, Channel 11) WPS 2.0 unlocked, signal -52 dBm
steps.explanation: Wash identifies routers with WPS enabled and shows lock status - unlocked means vulnerable to PIN attack

steps.action: Filter results to show only unlocked WPS access points
steps.expected_result: 5 unlocked WPS networks identified - 'HomeRouter-5G' has strongest signal and is primary target
steps.explanation: Filtering unlocked APs identifies most vulnerable targets - locked WPS has rate limiting defense

steps.action: Attempt Pixie Dust attack for rapid PIN recovery
steps.expected_result: Pixie Dust attack successful! WPS PIN recovered: 12345670 (completed in 8 seconds using offline attack)
steps.explanation: Pixie Dust exploits weak random number generation - recovers PIN without brute force

steps.action: Use recovered PIN to retrieve WPA2 password
steps.expected_result: WPS PIN confirmed valid - WPA2 PSK retrieved: 'xK9$mP2#nQ8@vL5&wR4' (20-character complex password bypassed via WPS)
steps.explanation: Even strong WPA2 password is useless when WPS PIN vulnerability exists

steps.action: Disable monitor mode after successful attack
steps.expected_result: Monitor mode disabled - wlan0 restored to managed mode
steps.explanation: Cleanup to restore normal wireless functionality

steps.expected_result: Successfully authenticated to 'HomeRouter-5G' using recovered password - full network access confirmed
steps.explanation: Validation step confirms credentials are correct and network access is possible

outcome: WPS vulnerability successfully exploited using Pixie Dust attack. Router's 20-character complex WPA2 password was bypassed completely through WPS PIN weakness. Attack completed in under 10 seconds. Recommended remediation: DISABLE WPS entirely in router settings - WPS convenience feature creates critical security vulnerability. If WPS needed, ensure firmware is updated and monitor for unauthorized connection attempts.
learning_objectives: Identify WPS-enabled routers using wash scanner
Distinguish between locked and unlocked WPS access points
Execute Pixie Dust attack for rapid PIN recovery
Understand why WPS undermines even strong passwords
Extract WPA2 credentials through WPS vulnerability
Provide effective remediation guidance for WPS vulnerabilities
